Course Section: ASIA_V 342-011 - Chinese Literature in Translation: The Vernacular Tradition
Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Delivery Mode -This is an in-person course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as ‘in-person’ are fully in-person for the entire term, including exams, and require in-person attendance to complete.

Course Topic: The Tale of GenjiWritten in the early 11th century by the court lady Murasaki Shikibu, The Tale of Genji is Japan’s most important literary work and the world’s first psychological novel. For over 1,000 years it has been read and re-read, illustrated and adapted, by artists and scholars, the nobility, samurai, and commoners. 
Over the course of the term students will read the text in its entirety translated in the language of their choice (English, Modern Japanese, Chinese, French, etc.). We will be paying particular attention to illustrations and visual adaptations of the Tale, from 12th century illustrated scrolls to contemporary manga and anime. The Tale of Genji has influenced virtually every aspect of Japanese culture and students will be encouraged to devise research projects that satisfy their individual interests, whether that be, for example, food or erotica. 
Delivery Mode -This is an in-person course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as ‘in-person’ are fully in-person for the entire term, including exams, and require in-person attendance to complete.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

For more information on this course, see: https://chinesefilmclassics.org/course/

Title: Queer/Early/Asias This course offers an introductory survey of gender and sexuality studies as applied to non-Western, non-contemporary contexts. We take up literary and visual texts from the pre-modern period to think about queer Asian pasts alongside contemporary secondary scholarship and regional creative adaptations that produce queer Asian futures. 

Delivery Mode -This is a synchronous hybrid course. Students are expected to meet synchronously twice per week (once per week on Zoom, and once per week in-person). Both of the synchronous sessions will involve graded coursework. All courses labelled as ‘hybrid’ have a mixture of mandatory in-person and online activities as designed by the instructor. While some components are online, in-person attendance IS required to complete the course. 

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

Title: Korean History Through FilmIn this course, we will explore modern Korean history through a cultural lens. Starting from the colonial period until the contemporary, each week will explore a milestone moment in Korea’s modern history and examine the relationship between history and culture. At times, we will study how culture of the time engaged with contemporaneous issues. At other times, we will examine how historical issues are remembered and reemployed in subsequent cultural works. Per week, there will be one film and two readings: one historical overview and one article analysing the film. In examining this link between history and film, students will gain a thorough knowledge of the key historical happenings that have shaped modern Korea, paying special attention to formations of gender, class, and national identities, as well as a deep understanding of the ways in which culture reflects/challenges/distorts history.

Delivery Mode -This is an in-person course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as ‘in-person’ are fully in-person for the entire term, including exams, and require in-person attendance to complete.

ATSC 313 is a hybrid, asynchronous course for all students.  All course content is available directly on the course website or through links to outside resources. There is no textbook for this course. All Quizzes and Assignments are open over a set number of days for students to complete when it fits best within their own schedule. These are then submitted online, through the Course Website. There are no lectures to attend or video lectures to follow. The only time students need to attend a session in-person is for the written final exam. The final exam will be written during the UBC exam period, at a time and date arranged by UBC Exam Services. All students will attend the final exam in-person in a UBC classroom.
